title: Are games really snowbally? Let's see the stats
body:
https://www.leagueofgraphs.com/rankings/win-stats/all

First blood gives a 60% winrate and a 40% loss rate. So just being the first team to have a death means you lose 10% of your odds to win. Okay technically a 20% loss in _odds,_ but a 10% loss in probability to win. 

Taking the first dragon gives you a 68% winrate. So if you get pushed in early botlane, tough luck, that dragon loss means a game loss 18% more often.

Taking Rift Herald gives a similar 70% winrate, mostly due to the fact that the team which is already winning has a much easier time taking Rift Herald in the first place. Not so much a cause of snowballing as a symptom. 

First Tower gives a **72% winrate**. So once a tower is down, that lane gets behind and can not catch up on farm because they now have to ward twice as much to keep on top of the minion wave safely. Meanwhile a first tower means that advantage starts spreading to other lanes, getting them ahead while the behind team tries to catch up.

Meaning if you die once in bot lane, your tower will fall, and you lose 22% to your odds of winning. Playing blackjack with no basic strategy or card counting gives you better odds of winning (42% vs 38%). 


So yes, it turns out the games are in fact ridiculously snowbally. These factors have always contributed to a rise in winrates, but in the past, first blood was something like 54% to win, and first tower 60%. 

There is no such thing as a comeback in 2018.

Oh and for fun, turns out warding doesn't matter anymore* because  a single mistake in laning makes a bigger difference than the impact an unwarded river does now.

https://www.leagueofgraphs.com/rankings/warding

First Tower: 72.27% WR

First Dragon: 68.74% WR

First Baron: 80.04% WR

First Inhib: 91.15%

So the numbers are practically identical actually

What matters is time scale though. If it takes 40 minutes to take the first inhib, as opposed to 20.

Of course. The mastery that seems to be flying under the radar is Triumph. It gives 25 gold per take down, regardless of the enemy's bounty, eliminating in large part the component of the game that rewards killing high-bounty targets.

Even the stacking defensive masteries are snowball oriented. Grasp rewards characters that can trade well by making their trading even better, and overgrowth rewards characters that can lane bully and counterjungling that sets that role behind. 

Conditioning is the only defensive rune that actually makes a difference if you durdle to get it active, while the hunter line and legend line make winning characters win more. 

No Fearless to protect against burst damage
No Seigemaster to protect from dives and make tower farming possible
No Legendary Guardian to improve defenses durring ganks and teamfights
No Toughskin, making characters that are bad at trading even worse at it
Bandit locked to bad support items preventing its use in hard matchups
Windspeaker equivalent lost its resistance boosting effect
Aftershock vs Courage of the Clossus only works better blocking extremely high burst damage (1000+) and is much worse at cc comboing to trade in-lane (a 5% health shield blocks damage entirely, 20% bonus resistances don't, and do nothing against true damage) 

The end result is only a handful of the tankiest of tanks that are overtuned can do the "play safe and farm up" route while everything else is throwing damage at each other 1- and 2-shotting and causing games to be decided by the 6 minute mark.
